dispel: make (a doubt, feeling, or belief) disappear.
Example:: the brightness of the day did nothing to dispel Elaine's dejection
fester: become worse or more intense, especially through long-term neglect or indifference
Example:: Let me dispel a few rumors so they don't fester into facts
iota: Example:: When you reach the 'chitta', the supreme consciousness, there is no iota of memory. It is pure intelligence.
excrement: waste matter discharged from the bowels; faeces. (can be used metaphorically too)
huddle up: To move close together to form a tightly packed group
Example:: The football team huddled up to discuss the next play.
pegged: fix; form a fixed opinion of; categorize
Example:: Funny I never pegged you as a cynic.
cynic: a person who believes that people are motivated purely by self-interest rather than acting for honourable or unselfish reasons.
Example:: some cynics thought that the controversy was all a publicity stunt
unfettered: Example:: Show me the heart unfettered by foolish dreams
marrow: the essential part of something (it has other physical meanings but this one seems to be more GRE-ish)
Example:: The Dead Poets were dedicated to sucking the marrow out of life.
swoon: Example:: Frankie's mother swooned and had to be helped to the headmaster's office
reconvene: convene or cause to convene again, especially after a pause in proceedings (convene means come or bring together for a meeting or activity; assemble)
rout: a disorderly retreat of defeated troops
Example:: the retreat degenerated into a rout
daunt: Example:: some people are daunted by technology
scaffold: a raised wooden platform used formerly for the public execution of criminals
nonchalant: (of a person or manner) feeling or appearing casually calm and relaxed; not displaying anxiety, interest, or enthusiasm
Example:: she gave a nonchalant shrug
agony: Example:: he crashed to the ground in agony
yawp: a harsh or hoarse cry or yelp; shout or exclaim hoarsely
Example:: Now Todd I would like you to give us a demonstration of a barbaric yawp.
preside: be in the position of authority in a meeting or other gathering
Example:: And my definition of a film director is "the man who presides over accidents."
campier: (of a man or his manner) ostentatiously and extravagantly effeminate
Example:: The little campier still, but masculine.
appellation: Example:: The city fully justifies its appellation ‘the Pearl of the Orient’
retain: continue to have (something); keep possession of
Example:: Even today we are retaining the same orthodox practices in many areas.
provenance: the place of origin or earliest known history of something.
Example:: an orange rug of Iranian provenance
impinge upon: to make an impression; have an effect or impact (usually followed by on or upon)
Example:: to impinge upon the imagination; social pressures that impinge upon one's daily life. to encroach; infringe (usually followed by on or upon): to impinge on another's rights.
disconsolate: very unhappy and unable to be comforted.
forestalled: prevent or obstruct (an anticipated event or action) by taking advance action.
evangelist: प्रचारक; prachar prasar garne manche; preacher
imperative: an essential or urgent thing.; of vital importance; crucial
wiry: lean and muscular and strong; sinewy
livestock: farm animals regarded as an asset
protracted: lasting for a long time or longer than expected or usual; prolonged; extended
piddling: pathetically trivial; trifling; insignificant; footling; small
slump: sit, lean, or fall heavily and limply;
Example:: she slumped against the cushions
astigmatic: refractive error in which the eye does not focus light evenly on the retina
mordant: Example:: a mordant sense of humour
aristocracy: the highest class in certain societies; the nobelity
steward: a person employed to manage another's property; agent; overseer;
upend: to end somthing or turn something upside down
equable: 1. even-tempered, calm;      2. not varying, stable, constant
mischievous: 1. naughty, bad, misbehaving;    2. malicious, malevolent, venomous
puckish: playful in a mischievous way; mischievous; playful
somber: 1. dark or dull in colour or tone; dark, dull;     2. having or conveying a feeling of deep seriousness and sadness., serious, grave, sober
uncouth: lacking good manners, refinement, or grace; uncivilized; uncultured
temper: (noun) state of mind; (verb) 1. harden, strengthen;   2. modify
irrefutable: that which cannot be denied; indisputable; undeniable;
wry: 1. sardonic, sarcastic, mocking    2. disgusted, displeased, discontended
revivification: give new life or vigour to
rejuvenation: look or feel better, younger, or more vital
abridge: shorten (a piece of writing) without losing the sense; shorten, cut, curtail
deterministic: believing that everything that happens must happen as it does and could not have happened any other way
hankering: a strong desire to have or do something
aggrieve: to make someone unhappy and angry
appraise: assess the value or quality of; evaluate
delinquency: minor crime, especially that committed by young people
mediation: arbitration; intervention in a dispute in order to resolve it
hysteria: exaggerated or uncontrollable emotion or excitement; frenzy; wildness
